catalog.title: Introductory Psychology
catalog.description: General survey of perception; learning and memory; cognitive, developmental, personality, abnormal, and social psychology; and behavioral neuroscience. Requires participation in research or a short paper.  This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade other than W may repeat the course in the summer or winter; or only in the fall or spring semester with a petition to the College of Arts and Sciences Deans' Office.
catalog.subject: Psychology

notes.note: Lectures will be posted online but there will also be multiple optional opportunities each week for students to interact with the professor and/or teaching assistants, in person or on Zoom. The only activities that will be required during the assigned class period will be taking the four exams. Time accommodations for exams will be given to students living abroad and with other documented time restrictions.

notes.note:
PSY MAJORS

Recorded lectures will be posted online. Instructor is available during office hours and individually scheduled appointments via web conferencing (Zoom) and via chat/messenger using GroupMe. Listed class times will be used for discussions, exams, and/or presentations - so students will be expected to be available at those times. Attendance at the live lectures will also be used for extra credit opportunities.

catalog.title: Mood Disorders
catalog.description: Contemporary ideas and research on mood disorders, including their classification, epidemiology, etiology, and treatment.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisite: Psychology majors only. PSY 322 recommended; 45 credits completed.
catalog.prerequisites: Psychology majors only. PSY 322 recommended; 45 credits completed

catalog.title: Self and Self-Esteem
catalog.description: Social psychological theory and research on the self. How the self-concept and self-esteem develop; consequences of self-views on affect, cognition, and behavior.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.

Attendance at the live lectures will also be used for extra credit opportunities. Instructor is available during office hours and individually scheduled appointments via web conferencing (Zoom) and via chat/messenger using GroupMe.

catalog.title: Adult Development & Aging
catalog.description: Developmental theory, methods, and empirical evidence needed to describe and understand the psychological changes that take place in adulthood and old age.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

catalog.title: Social Cognition
catalog.description: Overview of recent theory and research in social cognition, including automatic and controlled processing, stereotyping, social memory, and cultural influences on cognition.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: Psychology majors only, PSY 331 and 45 credits completed.
catalog.prerequisites: Psychology majors only, PSY 331 and 45 credits completed

catalog.title: Psychology and Law
catalog.description: Examines legal issues related to selected social problems in light of psychological theory, research, and clinical experience.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

catalog.title: Mind-Body in a Soc World
catalog.description: The connection between mind and body from a social psychological perspective; effects on various physiological systems; using body responses to understand psychological process.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.long_title: Mind-Body Connection in a Social World
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

catalog.title: Alcohol and Health
catalog.description: The relationship between alcohol use and psychological, social, and physical well-being.  Conceptualizes problem drinking within a social psychological paradigm; implications of different conceptions for the prevention and treatment of alcohol problems.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

catalog.title: Biopsych of Ingestive Behavior
catalog.description: Familiarizes students with the biological basis of feeding and drinking. Covers broader concepts including homeostasis, sensory systems, structure and function of the nervous system, chemical signaling, learning and public health, all in the context of the control of feeding and drinking.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: Psychology majors only. PSY 351 and 45 credits completed.
catalog.prerequisites: Psychology majors only. PSY 351 and 45 credits completed

catalog.title: Close Relationships
catalog.description: Focuses on current research and theory concerning close relationships.  Topics to be covered will include attachment, attraction, love, interdependence, communication, relationship conflict, social support, and health.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

catalog.title: History of Psychology
catalog.description: Historical antecedents and the evolution of contemporary theoretical approaches and concepts of psychology.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

notes.note: Lectures will occur live over zoom during the scheduled class time. Office hours will be held over zoom weekly by appointment. Weekly course assignments, discussion boards, quizzes and final case study paper will all be completed online.

catalog.title: Abnormal Child Psychology
catalog.description: Description, diagnosis, causes, and treatment of childhood disorders, including ADHD, aggression, depression, anxiety, autism, and others.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: PSY 424 Pre-Requisite: PSY 322 recommended; Psychology majors only.
catalog.requisites: PSY 424
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 322 recommended; Psychology majors only

catalog.title: Motivational Theory
catalog.description: Development of ideas concerning the problem of motivation; important experiments in the development of these ideas; current theories of motivation; data relevant to an examination of these theories.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

catalog.title: Communication in Animals
catalog.description: Focuses on the evolution, function, design, and diversity of animal communication systems such as song and visual signaling in birds, calls and echolocation in dolphins, echolocation and olfactory signaling in bats, olfactory signaling in insects, and electrical signaling in fish.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.long_title: The Neurobiology of Communication in Animals
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: Psychology majors only. PSY 351 and 45 credits completed.
catalog.prerequisites: Psychology majors only. PSY 351 and 45 credits completed

catalog.title: UB Seminar
catalog.description: The one credit UB Seminar is focused on a big idea or challenging issue to engage students with questions of significance in a field of study and, ultimately, to connect their studies with issues of consequence in the wider world.  Essential to the UB Curriculum, the Seminar helps transition to UB through an early connection to UB faculty and the undergraduate experience at a comprehensive, research university. This course is equivalent to any 198 offered in any subject.  This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade of F or R may not be able to repeat the course during the fall or spring semester.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Students who have already successfully completed the UB seminar course may not repeat this course. If you have any questions regarding enrollment for this course, please contact your academic advisor.
catalog.requisites: Students who have already successfully completed the UB seminar course may not repeat this course. If you have any questions regarding enrollment for this course, please contact your academic advisor

notes.note: Discover Mind and Brain. One of the most compelling questions in psychology is how the mind works, and the relationship between mental functioning and the physical brain. It is a question that was first addressed by philosophers, that psychologists have more recently tackled using the scientific method. In this seminar, we will explore how one studies minds, and the challenges involved in this endeavor. We will also discuss research concerning the contents of what is in our mind (sensory data), and the limits of the mind's ability to process this information. Finally, we will discuss how such mental functions are related to the physical activity of the brain, and how scientists understand this connection.

catalog.title: UB Seminar
catalog.description: The three credit UB Seminar is focused on a big idea or challenging issue to engage students with questions of significance in a field of study and, ultimately, to connect their studies with issues of consequence in the wider world.  Essential to the UB Curriculum, the Seminar helps students with common learning outcomes focused on fundamental expectations for critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and oral communication, and learning at a university, all within topic focused subject matter.  The Seminars provide students with an early connection to UB faculty and the undergraduate experience at a comprehensive, research university.  This course is equivalent to any 199 offered in any subject.  This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade of F or R may not be able to repeat the course during the fall or spring semester.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Students who have already successfully completed the first year seminar course may not repeat this course. If you have any questions regarding enrollment for this course, please contact your academic advisor.

catalog.title: Cognitive Neuroscience Methods
catalog.description: This course covers the application of neuroscientific methods to the study of human cognition, with a focus on  the analysis and interpretation of functional Neuroimaging data using the General Linear Model. Topics covered include the basic  principles  of  fMRI/PET/FNIRS/EEG, application of these methods to the study of normal and disordered cognitive processes including perception, memory, attention and reading. Students  will gain theoretical and hands- on experience with processing and analysis of BOLD MRI time series using the General Linear Model. These topics will be covered a sufficient  level to provide  students  with the ability to critically evaluate cognitive neuroscientific literature.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: 45 cr. completed and PSY 101 and PSY 350 and PSY 351.
catalog.prerequisites: 45 cr. completed and PSY 101 and PSY 350 and PSY 351

catalog.description: How we perceive, remember, and respond to music. Representation of musical knowledge, emotional and aesthetic response to music, listening styles of novices and experts, music's role in human culture.

MTH 115 OR EQUIVALENT

Lectures will be delivered during listed class times and recordings will be posted on UBLearns. Attendance at the live lectures will also be used for extra credit opportunities. Weekly homework assignments will be included to practice skills necessary for success in the course and on exams (which will be open for a 12 hour window overlapping with class time).

catalog.title: Psychological Statistics
catalog.description: Graphs; permutations; combinations; probability; regression; correlation; analysis of variance; descriptive and inferential statistics; parametric and nonparametric tests appropriate to psychological research. Three hours of lecture and one hour of recitation weekly.  This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade other than W may repeat the course in the summer or winter; or only in the fall or spring semester with a petition to the College of Arts and Sciences Deans' Office.

catalog.title: Hormones and Behavior
catalog.description: Familiarizes students with the structure, function, and principles of the endocrine/neuroendocrine system and how this system helps to initiate and regulate behavior (e.g. stress, reproduction, cyclicity in behavior, ingestion, and aggression).

catalog.prerequisites: Psychology majors only. PSY 351 and 45 credits completed

catalog.title: Adolescent Development
catalog.description: Emphasizes how growth and development during the adolescent period are influenced by contemporary culture.  Three major themes of adolescent development (self, stress, and love) are examined, and the course considers various psychological, biological, and sociological theories which attempt to explain changes associated with these themes.
catalog.subject: Psychology

Class participation exercises based on lecture material may be due within a specified time window (for example, 24 hours of lecture being posted) and everyone will have the same due dates for assignments (exceptions may be made for documented excuses).

catalog.title: Psychopharmacology
catalog.description: Basic brain chemistry and its influence on behavior. Distribution and elimination of drugs, drug-receptor interactions, and the neuroanatomical distribution of specific neurotransmitter systems. Special topics in biological psychiatry.

catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: Psychology majors only. PSY 351 and 45 credits completed.

catalog.title: Intro Cognitive Science
catalog.description: An interdisciplinary approach to the understanding of knowledge and mind, guided by principles of formal systems and computation. Concepts and approaches from psychology, philosophy, artificial intelligence, linguistics, and neuroscience. This course is the same as LIN 342 and course repeat rules will apply.  Students should consult with their major department regarding any restrictions on their degree requirements.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.long_title: Introduction to Cognitive Science: Concepts of the Mind

notes.note: This is an in-person section, where lectures are delivered during designated meeting times. Lectures are recorded and all course content can be completed asynchronously. Students are given an 18 hour window on designated dates to complete exams.  Students can visit weekly office hours in-person or via Zoom.

catalog.title: Sensory Proces & Perceptn
catalog.description: This class explores how humans and other animals sense the environment around them. We cover the structure and function of the sensory organs, the perceptual organization of the world, and the neurophysiology involved in sensation and perception. This course will also cover the history and theories of perception and the experimental data that support how we see, hear, taste, smell, and touch.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisite: PSY 101
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 101

notes.note: This is a remote section, where lectures are delivered during designated meeting times and recorded. All course content can be completed asynchronously. Students are given an 18 hour window on designated dates to complete exams.  Students can visit weekly office hours via Zoom.

catalog.title: Sensory Proces & Perceptn
catalog.description: This class explores how humans and other animals sense the environment around them. We cover the structure and function of the sensory organs, the perceptual organization of the world, and the neurophysiology involved in sensation and perception. This course will also cover the history and theories of perception and the experimental data that support how we see, hear, taste, smell, and touch.

catalog.prerequisites: PSY 101

catalog.title: Intro Laboratory Experience
catalog.description: This is a hands on class designed to take an early stage student through the scientific process including primary literature, data collection and presentation. This is a student centered classroom, active discussion and participation are required. At the conclusion of this course students should be competitive to begin research in other laboratories.
catalog.subject: Psychology

catalog.title: Cognitive Psychology
catalog.description: Information-processing approach to human behavior; how people interpret and understand the environment; recognition; memory; language.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisite: PSY 101
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 101

catalog.title: Health Psychology
catalog.description: Introduces the scientific study of the behavioral and social aspects of health.

Prerequisite: PSY 101

This is an asynchronous online class.  There are no set class meeting times. Recorded lectures will be posted online. Instructor is available during office hours and individually scheduled appointments via web conferencing. Assignments will be due throughout the semester and exams will be open for a 24-hour window.  This format is well-suited for students who want flexibility in when they work on course materials and are self-disciplined in setting their weekly schedule for classwork.

catalog.title: Psychology of Personality
catalog.description: Theory, research, and measurement related to the description, development, and dynamics of the normal personality.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisite: PSY 101
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 101

catalog.title: Comm for Psych Sciences
catalog.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the ways that psychologists communicate in scientific contexts, including writing technical research reports (journal articles), poster presentations at conferences, and oral presentations. You will learn how to structure a research report and write using the style guidelines of the American Psychological Association (APA). The aim will be to foster confidence in a scientific style of communication one that is often quite different from that taught in the humanities. Conciseness, clarity, and exactness will be the hallmarks of successful written and oral products in the course. At the completion of Communicating in Psychological Sciences, students should have developed each of these traits in their written and oral expression.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-requisite: Completion of Communication Literacy 1 or completion of Writing Skills 1 (ENG 101 or placement into ENG 201)
catalog.prerequisites: Completion of Communication Literacy 1 or completion of Writing Skills 1 (ENG 101 or placement into ENG 201)

catalog.prerequisites: Completion of Communication Literacy 1 or completion of Writing Skills 1 (ENG 101 or placement into ENG 201)

catalog.title: Comm for Psych Sciences
catalog.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the ways that psychologists communicate in scientific contexts, including writing technical research reports (journal articles), poster presentations at conferences, and oral presentations. You will learn how to structure a research report and write using the style guidelines of the American Psychological Association (APA). The aim will be to foster confidence in a scientific style of communication one that is often quite different from that taught in the humanities. Conciseness, clarity, and exactness will be the hallmarks of successful written and oral products in the course. At the completion of Communicating in Psychological Sciences, students should have developed each of these traits in their written and oral expression.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-requisite: Completion of Communication Literacy 1 or completion of Writing Skills 1 (ENG 101 or placement into ENG 201)
catalog.prerequisites: Completion of Communication Literacy 1 or completion of Writing Skills 1 (ENG 101 or placement into ENG 201)

catalog.title: Scientific Inquiry
catalog.description: The research process; observational, correlational and survey, experimental techniques; nature of theory; hypothesis testing and empirical data; scientific knowledge and its applications.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: PSY 207 Or STA 119.
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 207 Or STA 119

catalog.title: Biopsychology
catalog.description: Physiological studies, mainly on the nervous system, relevant to selected theoretical issues in perception, learning, motivation, and problem solving.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisite: PSY 101
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 101

catalog.title: Biopsychology
catalog.description: Physiological studies, mainly on the nervous system, relevant to selected theoretical issues in perception, learning, motivation, and problem solving.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisite: PSY 101
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 101

catalog.title: Conflict Resolution
catalog.description: Overview of social conflict theory and of conflict resolution practice. Topics include the nature and cause of conflict, strategic choice in conflict, escalation, negotiation, and third-party intervention. Emphasizes psychological approaches, but is not limited to them.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisite: PSY 101
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 101

notes.note: Recorded Lecture material and PowerPoints will be posted online. Instructor is available for office hours on zoom by appointment Monday- Friday. Assignments, discussions and quizzes will be due throughout the semester on blackboard and open for a week. Final exam will be on blackboard open for 48 hours.

catalog.title: Developmental Psychology
catalog.description: Major developmental changes in areas of human behavior, cognition, personality, and social life from the perspective of current theories about development across the lifespan.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisite: PSY 101
catalog.prerequisites: PSY 101

catalog.title: Supervised Teach
catalog.description: Undergraduate teaching assistant (UTA) positions are available for certain psychology courses to those students who have completed the course or its equivalent with a grade of A, have achieved junior status, and have a minimum GPA of 3.0 overall. Students must apply for UTA positions with the appropriate instructor. Credit does not count toward the major. Graded P/F.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

notes.note:
Members of the UB and Buffalo communities have been traveling to Mara, Tanzania, since 2009, collaborating with partners in support of women¿s empowerment and community development. You are invited to contribute your talents and expertise through related projects.
http://www.buffalo.edu/eln/students/project-portal/host-page.host.html/content/shared/www/eln/project-portal/topic-pages/active-topic-pages/empowering-women-and-girls-in-mara-tanzania.detail.html

catalog.title: Independent Study
catalog.description: A program of scholarship to be agreed upon by the student and a faculty sponsor in the department, including procedures for evaluating student performance. Student receives a letter grade.
catalog.subject: Psychology
catalog.requisites_description: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course.
catalog.requisites: Psychology majors only, 45 credits completed and completion of at least one 300 level PSY course

catalog.title: Superv Applied Exper
catalog.description: A program of applied work in a community, government, or private agency or organization related to the major in psychology. Must be agreed upon by the student and a faculty sponsor in the department. Credit does not count toward the major. Graded P/F.

notes.note: Focuses on a variety of topics regarding canine cognition and behavior such as dogs¿ perception of the world through sight, sound, and smell, canine communication, evolution and development of canine behavior, canine memory, dogs¿ understanding of abstract concepts, and more. This course will involve a combination of lectures, discussions, and activities examining current research on domestic dogs.

catalog.title: Topics
catalog.description: Current theories, research, and controversies in the major subareas of psychology. PSY 485-PSY 490 are part of the Cognitive and Behavioral neurosciences courses. Specific topics and content change each semester.
